name: Chocolate Taffy
headline: Chocolate Taffy
keywords: American,Candy Recipes and Ideas,Corn Recipes,Sugar,Dessert,Caramelizing,Gluten Free,Low-Fat
recipeIngredient: 1 1/2 tablespoons butter, plus additional for greasing pan and hands

recipeInstructions.text: In heavy medium saucepan, combine sugar, cocoa powder, and salt. Stir until thoroughly combined. Add corn syrup, water, and vinegar to pan and place over medium heat. Stir until sugar and cocoa dissolve, raise heat to high and bring to a boil. Turn heat down to low, clip candy thermometer to side of pan and cook until mixture reaches 260 degrees F. Remove pan from heat, add the butter and stir. Butter edges of sheet pan, line with silicone baking sheet and pour on taffy. Allow to cool until you are able to handle it.

Once you are able to handle the taffy, don vinyl gloves, butter them, and begin to fold taffy in thirds using the silicone mat. Pick up taffy and begin to pull folding the taffy back on itself repeatedly twisting as you go. Taffy is done when it lightens in color, takes on a sheen, and becomes too hard to pull. Roll into log, cut into fourths, roll each fourth into a 1-inch wide log, and cut into 1-inch pieces. Making sure to keep pieces separated or they will stick to each other. Wrap individual pieces of candy in waxed paper. Store in airtight container 3 to 5 days.

review.reviewBody: The taste is great!  I thought the texture was a bit more "nibsish" than "tootsie".  The next time I make these I'm going to aim more to the "soft ball" stage than hard ball.  I think that would make for a softer chewier taffy.

As I have an electric cook top, my advice is to use two burners, one for high till it boils and then quickly switch it to a low heat burner with the candy thermometer.  Otherwise it cooks too quickly and does not harden.  I loved it. I used a new product called nonstick baking paper, much cheaper than the silicone and it worked perfectly! Very happy with the taffy.  I wrapped as directed and hopefully it won't stick! Good recipe. The tough part is waiting till it is cool enough to lift from the paper! Alton, this is a great recipe, will definately pull out my fillings!!!

I think there is a big difference between gas ranges and electric when it comes to candy making. I learned to make candy when I was a child and have done it every year. Move out on my own with an electric stove top and never could get the recipe to work. It wouldn't rise to the temperature with out cooking to fast and getting gritty. After several failed attempts on different stoves I went back over to Mom's who had a different gas stove than before and it worked perfectly. Couldn't be the altitude because we live within a few miles of each other. Has anyone else haad this happen or am I imagining things?

After seeing this episode on a Halloween special, my step daughter and I decided to try it.  I was a little worried about trying it after reading the reviews, especially since I did not have a candy thermometer and it was my first attempt at making candy.  Instead I tried the cold water test and it worked perfectly!  I couldn't have gotten better results.  It took about 30-40 mins for my candy to get to temperature, on just above the lowest setting on my gas stove.  Fantastic recipe, I will definitely be making more of these!
Fantastic show. I love watching Good Eats. I learn alot from this show. Please dont ever take this show off the air. Thank You

In the show Alton mentions that saltwater taffy is made with sea water. AN old wives tale and myth. Sea water was never used to make saltwater taffy, the taffy simply got its name as it was made in a shop on the wharf, overlooking the sea. And to tmommy12, yes altitude does change the temperature, don't quote me, but I believe higher altitude, lower temp. Should be able to find it online here somewhere. According to all recipes, for every 500 feet above sea level, reduce temp by 1 degree for sugar candy making.

Help! 2 thoughts: either high altitude changes this recipe with the boiling pts AND/OR I waited too long to handle it b/c I put my twins down for nap right after we poured it out onto the sheet. Either way, ugh! I followed everything perfectly, but I noticed that once it was boiling and the thermometer went in, something went wrong. I put stove to low and temp seemed to get stuck around 220 and wouldn't go up, so I had to start slowly increasing temp to get it up to 260.  Maybe it cooked way too long. Then, came back, put on my gloves and the candy just snapped into sharp pieces. Tastes great, but will have to keep sharp pieces out of my toddlers' mouths.  Bummer!
It turned out a bit harder than normal taffy (although I got a bit lazy and didn't pull it as much as I should have) but it tasted delicious.

Forgive me but anyone who "gets blisters" on their hands as a result of doing this recipe is a total TOOL!!  This is not super easy to make, no, but the results of being patient and following the recipe are awesome.  THis is GREAT Chocolate Taffy and Alton Brown is the best!!!!!  Also loved his Super Apple Pie!!

This was not good at all...took way too long to get to temp, as in other reviews.  Also, got blisters (even using gloves) from pulling and hard to pull.  Candy way to hard to chew, threw half of it out.  But using the rest as hard candy similar to Werther's.  Not sure what went wrong except it must have cooked too long waiting for it to get to 260 degrees.  Probably will stick to just buying tootsie rolls from now on.

As someone else said, follow the instructions exactly.  Don't cook it too fast, make sure you have a reliable candy thermometer and take it off the heat as soon as it hits the right temperature, wear the vinyl gloves as described (hands sticking to the taffy is what can cause blisters and unless you're constantly greasing them this is likely).  And pull it for long enough until it lightens in color - if you don't pull it long enough it will be hard.  10-15 minutes is to be expected.  I'm an average-sized woman of average strength and I and my 4 and 7 year olds didn't have any trouble pulling this.

I am a teacher in TN and we make this taffy yearly for Halloween in science class. (great physical sci lesson in chemical and physical change). The kids hear about it from friends in the upper grades now, and it has become a tradition. The kids tell me that it si the best taffy they have ever had, and no store bought tootsie would ever be its equal. I would have to agree, as AB has this one right. It is chocolatey heaven. Yum! Try it!

Don't let some of these reviews chase you off from trying this recipe, If you can follow directions and you have the necessary tools, it's easy and it's good!

Some helpful hints --

1.) Use good chocolate and fresh ingredients
2.) Use a silicon mat
3.) Drop the heat immediately after it hits the boiling point (212), then take the heat low enough so that the heat continues to rise to 260
4.) Don't try to cut with a knife, use kitchen scissors and keep them clean

As for the comments about burning your hands and causing blisters -- I'm not sure how this could happen. Wait for the total cooling period and then start folding. It is not too hot to handle after about 10 minutes. (My hands are sensitive to temperature -- it was not painful at all.) Once folded, the pulling is pretty simple, it will give your arms a bit of a workout. As for the comments about what it does to you hands, not my experience at all and my hands are not hardened from callouses. No need for a mechanical puller! You can do it.

As with any candy, patience is the key. Give it a try, it is fun and easy.
the chacolate is so soft and chewy love it so much the best

I thought this would be a fun and tasty treat for myself and my teenage sons...and it was. I haven't made taffy in a long time, but the simplicity of the recipe's ingredients and it being chocolate was all the motivation I needed.

I didn't have the dutch processed cocoa powder, so I just used what I always have, and I was not dissappointed. It takes awhile for it to reach the correct temp., but my patience was well worth it. I poured the hot taffy onto a greased cookie sheet and let it cool for the recommended 10-15 min. and it wasn't too hot for me to pull while wearing food gloves. Between my 14 yr old son and I we pulled and then we cut (using scissors) into bite sized pieces.

YUMMMMM!!!

Come on Alton! I really love your show but this recipe was just... bad. It was hard to make, my hands burned from the pulling and twisting [if it is too cold you can't pull but if it is too hot it burns], and it didn't taste that good to me. Cutting it was so hard as well. I am 16 and although I made these, it was tough and I didn't enjoy the outcome. My mom liked the way they tasted so maybe it is just me :[.

I followed the directions almost exactly, but this taffy came out like a rock. It may have something to do with the lack of pulling.

What Alton doesn't warn you about is that for your hands, 10 minutes of pulling is equivalent to about 2 hours of shoveling. For those without calloused hands (most of his fans, I'm sure), the pulling causes significant friction blisters. I pulled until I realized that I had blisters about to break, and bodily fluids are not good eats. I cut it up, hoped for the best, and let it cool. It's a nice hard candy that threatens to pull out dental work.

I'm thinking that the hard ball stage (I had 2 thermometers say that I never got over 258 degrees) may too much for the "tootsie roll" consistency mentioned in the show. I'm thinking maybe firm ball (250) would make a softer candy. That, or I need to build a mechanical puller.
This was great and very fun to make! to cut it is easier to use scissors.

This recipe took way to long to get to the right temperature, nearly 1.25 hrs and it was absolutely impossbile to get to the right stage when pulling and folding.  I have blisters on the insides of both of my thumbs.  The cand is so hard I can't cut it into fourths to roll into logs to cut into individual pieces.  I recommend you only make this recipe if you have a mechanical puller.
i didnt like this recipe at all it took almost 1 hour for the taffy to get to the right temp. and then it tasted gross

I made this to give to people for Halloween, and it's very good. Mine came out just a wee bit too chewy, but that might've been because I didn't have enough corn syrup. Also, the wax wrappers make them so cute :)

Great tasting taffy, but it never hardening up, even after an hour or more of pulling!  My husband thinks that maybe he didn't cook it enough.  He brought it to a boil, lowered the heat and put in the thermometer and it was already at 260 degrees so he took it off the heat.  Any suggestions on what to do differently would be appreciated!  We'd love to get this right!

This is a great recipe. Although it takes a lot of time, it was very easy to follow the directions. they reminded me of tootsie rolls, but much better.

The recipe makes a lot of candies, so be prepared to give some away!

These are SO chocolaty. Just be careful and don't use a newer candy thermometer that you aren't sure how to read. Mine came out too hard once they cooled, but the second batch I used my OLD thermometer and they came out perfect. Chewy and yummy.
